thread.title: Check out New York City’s most expensive rental pad | Real Estate | Property Real Estate
thread.title_full: Check out New York City’s most expensive rental pad | Real Estate | Property and Real Estate | | The Advertiser

author: Hana R Alberts
title: Check out New York City’s most expensive rental pad | Real Estate | Property Real Estate
text:
IT WILL be no trouble to live in New York’s most expensive rental apartment — as long as you have US$150,000 ($203,000) per month to spare.
The 416-square-metre pad on the 65th floor of One57, the first complete building on 57th Street’s Billionaires’ Row, has three bedrooms, four-and-a-half bathrooms and floor-to-ceiling windows showcasing Central Park views, the New York Post reports .
Bird’s eye ... floor-to-ceiling windows showcase Central Park views. Picture: Douglas Elliman Source: Supplied
Yes, this is the building that houses the most expensive apartment ever sold in New York City — a palatial duplex on its 89th and 90th floors, which went for a whopping US$100,471,452.77 late last year to an anonymous buyer.
Other features include high ceilings, brand-name appliances and a master suite with three walk-in closets and two marbled master baths.
Room with a view ... the master suite has three walk-in closets and two marbled master baths. Picture: Douglas Elliman Source: Supplied
To get technical, it’s the fifth most-expensive rental in the entire city, according to real estate listing site StreetEasy.
But any pricier pad you could lease are all in hotels — two at the Pierre for US$500,000 and US$400,000 per month, and two at the Surrey for US$450,000 and US$300,000.
This One57 pad’s extravagant price tag is mostly due to its location in a high-profile building, but there are some perks, too. Residents have access to a gym, yoga studio, business centre, bike storage and a party room with a kitchen caterers can use. There’s also permission to swim in the pool at the Park Hyatt, the five-star hotel that takes up the bottom 25 floors of One57.
Making plans ... the 416-square-metre pad on the 65th floor of One57, the first complete building on 57th Street’s Billionaires’ Row, has three bedrooms and four-and-a-half bathrooms. Picture: Douglas Elliman Source: Supplied
The facade, which has a distinctive smattering of blue-grey glass panels, is designed by Pritzker Prize-winning architect Christian de Portzamparc, while the interiors are by Danish-born NYC-architecture superstar Thomas Juul-Hansen.
Unfortunately, this apartment comes unfurnished — try to look past some virtual staging with rather unattractive furniture and just enjoy the view. (And baulk at that price.)
The property is listed for rent by Douglas Elliman.
Perks ... residents have permission to swim in the pool at the Park Hyatt, the five-star hotel that takes up the bottom 25 floors of One57. Picture: Douglas Elliman Source: Supplied
